Dear Ana Claire McClain:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Jessica VandenHeuvel, the area manager at (616) 204-
6992.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Program statement
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109 Program statement
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents’ needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 06/29/2024 around 3:48pm, Staff 1 and Staff 2 left the unit with
who they believed were all the youth. At around 5:46pm, Staff 1
and Staff 2 realized Youth A was not with the group and called
back to the unit supervisor to see if Youth A was left there.
Supervisor 1 checked the camera and saw Youth A was there and
made it to the unit at 6:14pm so he was no longer unsupervised.
Youth A was not harmed and reported he was sleep and did not
realize that they had left until he woke up.
Investigation Complainant was interviewed via phone on 7/1/2024 and
again face to face at the facility on 7/2/2024. He reported
receiving a phone call from Staff 1 on Saturday 6/29/24 at
approximately 5:46PM who informed Complainant that the unit
went on an outing and mistakenly left Youth A at the unit.
Complainant checked the live video feed and observed Youth A
sitting on the couch watching television on the unit. Complainant
went to the unit, arriving at approximately 6:14PM and spoke with
Youth A. Youth A informed Complainant that Youth A was “fine”
and needed nothing. Complainant reported Staff 1 informed him
that the group left the unit at approximately 3:38PM and it was a
“little over two hours” when noticing Youth A was not present. He
reported the process staff are to follow for an outing includes staff
communicating about who they are taking on the outing, and what
supervision is provided for youth staying behind. He believed staff
did not communicate with each other to ensure all youth were
present.
Administrator was interviewed via phone on 7/1/2024, face to
face at the facility on 7/2/2024 and again via video conference
on 7/5/2024. She reported the staff did not follow the supervision
policy and she will provide this policy plus all other information
requested. Staff 1 and Staff 2 used two vans to transport the youth
on the outing and it appears that they had communication issues.
2

The plan for staff at this time is that they will not engage in outings
and will not work on the unit alone until this investigation is
completed. She reported Supervisor 2 who was on campus was
notified and sent to the unit prior to Complaiant’s visit to the unit to
check on Youth A. She reported staff are to do “head checks” as
outlined in the policy even when on outings.
Youth A was interviewed at the facility face to face on
7/2/2024. An interpreter was used due to Youth A having very
limited English skills. Youth A reported being in the program for
the past 3 to 4 months and feeling safe but unsafe when alone.
Youth A reported not being sure what occurred that he was left
alone. He recalled being informed by staff (believes both Staff 1
and Staff 2) that the unit was going on an outing, but Youth A
informed Staff 2 that he wanted to stay behind. Youth A reported
Staff 2 came to him about 3:30PM and asked again about going
and Youth A told her he was not interested in going on the outing.
Youth A went to his bedroom and when awaking he found
everyone else gone. Youth A reported not wanting to go on the
outing because he believed the group was going to be playing in
the water and Youth A didn’t want to engage in this activity. Youth
A reported it has always been an option to not engage in outing
but there has always been staff that stay behind to supervise.
Youth A reported a supervisor (unable to identify) came to the unit
around 5:00PM and spoke with Youth A.
Staff 1 was interviewed at the facility face to face on 7/2/2024.
He reported getting to the beach and realizing Youth A was
missing from the group. At that time, Staff 1 called Complainant.
He reported leaving with the group from the facility at
approximately 3:50PM. Staff 2 was checking on all of the youth
while Staff 1 got items ready for the outing. They arrived at the
beach at approximately 5:00PM and after another youth
(unidentified) asked where Youth A was, staff realized that Youth
A was missing. Staff 1 reported not completing a “head count”
prior to leaving and having one youth change vans just prior to
leaving the facility. He reported there was a lack of communication
between himself and Staff 2 as to each number of youths in the
two vans. Staff 1 reported being told by Staff 2 Youth A informed
her that he was not interested in going on the outing when Staff 1
realized Youth A was missing on the beach. Staff 1 reported
speaking with Staff 2 about the situation and both realizing they
made a mistake.
Supervisor 2 was interviewed via phone on 7/2/2024. He
reported receiving a phone call from Complainant about a youth
3

being left at the facility by staff when the unit went on an outing.
Complainant asked Supervisor 2 to go to the unit to ensure the
safety of Youth A because Complainant was 10-minutes away.
Supervisor 2 went to the unit but because he had yet to be cleared
by ORR to enter the unit (has only had current position for 5
months and needs clearance from ORR to enter the program), he
stood in the hallway and waited for Complainant to arrive.
Supervisor 2 could hear music from the unit but never visibly
observed Youth A.
Staff 2 was interviewed via phone on 7/5/2024. She reported
focusing on prepping for the activity and making sure there was
enough snacks and water for the youth. She reported going into
Youth A’s room at approximately 3:15PM and Youth A told her
Youth A didn’t want to go. Youth A then told Staff 2 Youth A was
open to going and Staff 2 informed Youth A to be in the milieu
area at 3:30PM. Staff 2 reported a belief that Youth A was going
to go at that time. Once at the park around 5:45PM, another youth
(unidentified) asked about Youth A and Staff 1 and Staff 2 realized
Youth A was missing. Staff 2 reported missing the head count of
youth and was unable to explain what had occurred to leaving
Youth A behind. She reported both she and Staff 1 made mistakes
in their supervision of the youth in their care. Staff 2 assumed
Staff 1 had the other youth in his van because she had three
youth in her van during the trip to the park.
Documents Reviewed:
Wedgwood Christian Services Client Safety Policy 05-09
dated 4/18/2018. This document outlines staff’s responsibilities to
keep youth safe and secure while in care. It is documented that
this includes the responsibility of specific supervision practices
necessary to ensure safety. It is also documented that staff are to
conduct “head counts” of youth no less often than every fifteen
minutes.
Wedgwood Christian Services Activity Treatment –
Residential Staff Expectations dated 8/31/2018. This document
outlines staff’s expectation during activities. It is documented that
staff are to make certain that there is no unsupervised interaction
among youth during the activity.
Staff 1’s personnel file: Documentation indicates Staff 1 was
hired on 2/17/2023 and there is no disciplinary action documents
in the file. Staff 1 is current on his training.
4

Staff 2’s personnel file: Documentation indicates Staff 2 was
hired on 11/20/2023 and there is no disciplinary action documents
in the file. Staff 2 is current on her training.
Analysis The agency is found in non-compliance as evidence by Staff 1,
and Staff 2’s admitting to not following policy and providing
appropriate supervision to Youth A during an outing in which
Youth A was left by himself at the facility. There is also no
evidence that Staff 1 and Staff 2 completed the required “head
counts” every 15-minutes.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
Technical assistance was offered to the facility in the aspect of
developing a check list to be taken during an outing to ensure the
15-minute “head counts” are completed and to ensure all youth
are present. Head Checks should be documented so this action
can be proven to have taken place.
Additionally, when the agency determines a youth is left
unsupervised, it is imperative that youth safety be the priority and
verification of safety be completed regardless of outside
expectations.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established
2023C0000002 Dated 10/31/22, CAP approved 12/22/22.
2023C0000274 Dated 7/27/23, CAP approved 5/26/23.
5

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
